Award.AwardTitle: HBCU-DCL EAGER: Unraveling Academic Success: Identifying High Impact Practices to Support Academic Persistence and Degree Completion for Underrepresented Populations in Engineering

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
Growing a talented STEM workforce is critical to ensuring America's future advancement. The creation of this desired STEM workforce is vital to virtually all of our national goals' accelerating economic prosperity, maintaining global competitiveness, securing national defense, creating clean and renewable energy sources, protecting the quality of our air, water, soil and environment, and advancing national health solutions for all citizens. This project responds to the challenge of growing a diverse talented engineering workforce by conducting research to identify the specific educational policies, practices, and programs that impact diverse students' academic persistence to degree completion within the engineering enterprise. The outlined research activities will yield results that identify high impact practices that positively influence student learning outcomes, academic persistence, and graduation rates of under-represented students in engineering majors.

This research utilizes a mixed-method case study of underrepresented students currently enrolled in or alumni of the College of Engineering at a historically black college and university, located in the southeastern part of the country. Specifically, interviews utilizing open-ended questions with current and former engineering graduate students, alumni, and faculty in the College of Engineering will be implemented to accomplish the following: (a) reveal the policies, programs and practices that impact students? willingness to persist to degree completion; and, (b) identify the components of the policies, programs and practices perceived by students to be concentric to their success. Additionally, the project will include survey data collections that will help triangulate interview findings. Thus, a blueprint for designing and implementing institutional practices, procedures, and policies proven to ensure the success of diverse students in Engineering degree programs will be created.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research supported the creation of a talented, competitive, and diverse future Engineering workforce that is vital to fulfilling our national goals—economic prosperity, global competitiveness, stronger national defense, the creation of clean and renewable energy sources, the quality of our air, water, soil and environment as well as engineering advanced systems and medicines to ensure the health and welfare of our citizens.

This research has identified the High Impact Practices (HIPs) most conducive to engineering students’ academic persistence and college completion within the field of engineering. Additionally, given the contributions of HBCUs to the production of STEM majors, this case study of engineering students at TSU generated lessons that can impact all programs with a desire to broaden participation in STEM fields.  Data results derived illustrate the importance of high impact practices on the persistence and completion of underrepresented students majoring in Engineering. HIP practices identified as being successful in the preliminary data findings include mentoring, involvement in research activities, professor interaction, family and peer support.

The results of this research are helping to inform Engineering Education at HBCUs to ensure academic persistence and graduation of URMs. Thus, these findings will aid in producing national strategies that can be replicated to ultimately produce the diverse Engineering workforce that is required to meet the challenges facing our nation. As a result of successfully completing the aforementioned research, a blueprint for designing and implementing institutional practices, procedures, and policies proven to ensure the success of diverse students in engineering programs will be created. The creation of this blueprint will allow valuable information to be shared among graduate program faculty, staff, students, administrators, and other key persons at HBCUs and other institutions. Thus, helping to ensure the rapid adoption, adaptation, and implementation of proven best practices within engineering programs throughout the nation. Also, this blueprint will serve as a valuable resource to the national STEM community. Hence, this blueprint will become the conduit by which graduate programs can successfully produce the talent needed to fuel the Engineering workforce of the future.

The impact of the project will reach all STEM fields nationally. University Program Staff and Administrators can utilize the survey instruments created, research plan and protocol created, results obtained, products produced, and workshops/training produced from this project to improve STEM programs and education nationwide while increasing the diversity of the STEM workforce.

The results obtained, products produced, and workshops/training developed from this project will support the success of HBCUs, students and faculty/administrators involved in STEM programs. The project outcomes will foster the rapid dissemination of key information for the improvement of student persistence, individual factors, environmental factors, institutional practices, procedures, and policies.

The project focus on improving STEM education (i.e., broadening participation, supporting student persistence) will advance the overall STEM workforce. The cultural and academic considerations of this project aim to impact the future workforce of the nation creating a cycle of success and equity to advance STEM opportunities for all members of society. 

 


Last Modified: 06/09/2020
Modified by: Lesia L Crumpton-Young
